Abstract: 1
The mismatch between the distribution of water resources and the industrial structure has led to an 2 increasingly prosperous regional trade, with many water resources flowing from the production to the 3 consumption regions. This paper maps the inside and outside virtual water trade of the Yellow River 4 Basin, applying the environmentally extended input-output model to evaluate the external dependence 5 of water in the Yellow River Basin. The results show that the Yellow River Basin mobilizes 27.2 billion 6 of virtual water flowing into other regions despite water scarcity, equivalent to half the runoff of the 7 Yellow River. The leading destination for outflow is the Eastern coast, and the largest virtual water 8 outflow sector is Agriculture and Manufacturing. The inequity of the inside virtual water trade of the 9 Yellow River Basin is severe, with large amounts of virtual water flowing from poor to rich regions. It 10 exacerbates water scarcity in poor regions. 11 Key words: Water scarcity; Sustainable development; Yellow River Basin; Virtual water trade; Water 12 management; 13

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 14
sections.text:
Water is a vital resource that profoundly affects human survival, industrial development, and social 15
progress(Deng et al., 2023). Since industrialization, the consumption of water resources has increased 16
significantly(Hou et al. 2023). Global water demand, driven by population growth, economic 17
development, and urbanization, increased nearly eight times between 1900 and 2010(Muñoz et al. 2020). 18
The scarcity of water resources also limits economic development(Wu et al. 2022; Ekmekcioğlu et al. 19
2022), especially in water-scarce regions, such as China(Zhao et al. 2020). Over-exploitation of some 20
river basins has caused groundwater depletion, seriously affecting water security. Among them, the 21
Yellow River Basin (YRB) is particularly serious. With the development of the economy, the demand for 22
food and energy in China will further increase. Water is a prerequisite for food production and energy 23
extraction(Zhang et al. 2020a; Pang et al. 2021; Liu et al. 2023). As an essential grain and energy base 1
in China, the YRB faces a severe water shortage problem(Cao et al. 2023). 2
The Yellow River (YR), the second-largest river in China, contains seven urban agglomerations 3
along its route. The Yellow River basin (YRB) is a priority area for constructing ecological civilization 4
in China. In 2020, the Chinese government proposed the Ecological conservation and high-quality 5
development of the Yellow River Basin. The runoff of the YR is less than 7% of that of the Yangtze River 6
(the longest river in China)(Liu et al. 2021). In 2021, the YRB accounted for 29.8% of the country's 7
population, but its per capita water resources are only 30% of the national average. Water scarcity has 8
seriously affected the sustainable development of the YRB. Despite this, the YRB remains a vital food 9
base for China(Wang et al. 2023). With 13% of its grain production area, the YRB supplies more than 10
35% of the country's grain. The uneven distribution of high-water-consuming industries and 11
unreasonable water allocation exacerbate limited water wastage in the socioeconomic system and 12
threaten regional water security(Jia et al. 2021; Cai and Guo 2023). 13
Rational allocation of water resources is the key to alleviating water shortage and achieving 14
ecological protection and high-quality development(Lei et al. 2022; Ma et al. 2023). Several efforts have 15
been made to alleviate water shortages. The first is the direct adjustment of water resources for 16
redistribution and storage. This mainly includes direct water transfer, the construction of canals, dams, 17
reservoirs, and other projects(Liu et al. 2021), and unconventional water consumption (Yazdandoost et 18
al. 2021). The property that waters is challenging to transport makes physical water transfer 19
extraordinarily costly and difficult to build(Purvis & Dinar, 2020). Second, water-saving technology is 20
popularized from the perspective of demand. The main focus is agriculture(Surendran et al. 2021), and 21
high water-consuming industries(Wireko-Gyebi et al. 2022). However, spreading water-saving 22
technologies can only slightly alleviate water shortages but cannot permanently solve water scarcity in 1
water-scarce regions. 2
In response to the increasing pressure on scarce water resources, researchers have developed the 3
concept of virtual water, which refers to the amount of water embedded in a good or service, including 4
the water consumed in its production and delivery(Teymouri and Dehghanzadeh 2021). Virtual water 5
trade (VWT) has less negative environmental impact and lower economic input than traditional 6
transregional water transfers(Liu et al. 2022). VWT is essential to alleviate water scarcity(Zhao et al. 7
2015; Du et al. 2022; Hirwa et al. 2022). 8
In recent years, the research on virtual water has been increasing, providing new perspectives on 9
regional water resources management. There are two main approaches to studying virtual water, one is 10
the top-down type, and the other is the bottom-up type. The bottom-up approach uses a rigorous 11
mathematical model to account for virtual water for specific products using a large amount of data(An et 12
al. 2021; Lachaut et al. 2022). However, the method is highly demanding for data and makes it difficult 13
to portray the VWT relationship between different sectors between regions(Yin et al. 2021). Therefore, 14
at this stage, the top-down approach is mainly used to account for VWT. Studies have systematically 15
analyzed VWT patterns based on multi-regional input-output models (Graham et al. 2020; Islam et al. 16
2021). In international trade, multi-regional input-output tables were constructed using global trade data, 17
and a global VWT network was developed by combining sectoral water consumption data(Falsetti et al., 18
2022; Mekonnen & Hoekstra, 2020). The study found that developing countries undertake many water-19
intensive products, sacrificing water resources in exchange for economic rewards(Maroufpoor et al. 20
2021). On a national scale, studies have quantified VWT in each of China's provinces(Wang et al. 2022). 21
Each year, many virtual flows from northern China are directed to the south, which is the opposite of the 22
distribution of water resources in China(Zhang & Anadon, 2014)). Water scarcity affects the volume of 1
VWT, and inter-provincial trade has exacerbated water scarcity in water-scarce regions of China. The 2
integration of regional water management and VWT is essential for the sustainable utilization of regional 3
water resources(Dalin et al., 2015; Jing et al., 2022). 4
However, most studies still focus on global VWT and international VWT. Few studies have been 5
conducted on the inside and outside VWT of the water-scarce basins. Virtual water trade studies at the 6
basin scale for water-scarce basins can clarify the relationship between regional water resources and 7
industrial structure, which supports the sustainable development of urban clusters in the basin. In addition, 8
adjusting the capacity of water-intensive industries according to the VWT nexus can alleviate regional 9
water scarcity problems. However, only a few studies have been conducted at the basin level. 10
This study aims to reveal the characteristics of the inside and outside VWT of the YRB. We make 11 policy recommendations to achieve sustainable water management in the YRB and contribute to national 12 strategies for the Ecological conservation and high-quality development of the Yellow River Basin. First, 13 we obtain regional multisectoral water withdrawal from the local perspective by collecting, integrating, 14 and calibrating water consumption data. Second, we map and analyze the inside and outside VWT of the 15 YRB. Finally, we provide policies to achieve sustainable water management in YRB from the VWT 16 perspective. 17

sections.heading: 2.5. Data Source 3
sections.text:
The multi-regional input-output table used in this paper is based on the China multiregional input-4
output table published by Carbon Emission Accounts and Datasets for emerging economies in 2015 5
(Zheng et al. 2021). We divided China's 27 provinces and four municipalities (except Taiwan Province) 6
by geographical location. Since the relevant data for each province cannot be fully matched with the 7
multi-regional input-output table, we merge the sectors in the input-output table into seven sectors (see 8
Appendix A for detailed sector merging). 9
Primary economic data for each province were obtained from the statistical yearbook published by 10
the National Bureau of Statistics. Industrial water intensity by industry was obtained from the China 11
High-Resolution Emissions Network dataset (Cai et al. 2018). The intensity of water withdrawal was 12
calculated by dividing the sectoral water withdrawal by the sectoral output value. Total water resources 13
by province, actual average water withdrawal per acre for irrigated arable land, and effective utilization 14
coefficient for irrigated farmland were obtained from the Water Resources Bulletin issued by the Ministry 15
of Water Resources. The irrigated farmland area was sourced from the local water resources bulletin. The 16
value of the industrial sector in each city was taken from the statistical yearbook of each city. Data on 17
grain production by province were taken from national grain production data released by the National 18
Bureau of Statistics. 19

3.1. Comparison of water consumption under production-based accounting and consumption-21
based accounting 22
As shown in Fig. 1, the water consumption of the YRB based on consumption-based accounting 1
(CBA) (107.3 billion m³) is higher than the water consumption based on production-based accounting 2
(PBA) (105.3 billion m³). The overall intensity of water consumption in the YRB (3.6 m³/1000 yuan) is 3
slightly higher than the national average (4.5 m³/1000 yuan), with significant differences between the 4
upper and lower reaches. Based on the accounting of PBA or CBA, water consumption in downstream 5
provinces is higher than in upstream provinces. Compared to PBA, water consumption in downstream 6
provinces increases significantly under CBA while generally decreasing in midstream and upstream 7
provinces. Based on this change, we refer to the provinces with higher water consumption under CBA 8
than under PBA as consumption-oriented provinces and the rest as production-oriented provinces. 9
accounting for 22.1% of the total water consumption in the YRB. The downstream regions account for 13
34.0% of total water consumption in the YRB. The most negligible water consumption in the YRB is in 14
Qinghai (3.1 billion m³), accounting for only 3.0% of the total water consumption in the YRB. The 15
highest water consumption intensity consumption is in Shandong (2.0 m³/1000 yuan), only 55.2% of the 16
average in the YRB, followed by Shaanxi (2.5 m³/1000 yuan). The remaining upstream provinces have 1
water intensities higher than the YRB average. Gansu has the lowest water consumption intensity (11.0 2
m³/1000 yuan), three times the intensity of the YRB, and six times the intensity of the Shandong province. 3
Although Shandong consumes 1.6 times more water than Gansu, it creates 8.1 times more economic 4
output. 5
As shown in Figure 2, Agriculture is the sector that uses the most water in all provinces. The 6
province with the highest water consumption in Agriculture is Sichuan (15.7 billion m³), which represents 7
67.5% of the total water consumption in the province. The province with the highest share of Agriculture 8
water consumption is Gansu (9.6 billion m³), accounting for 87.2% of total water consumption. In 9
contrast, water consumption in the Manufacturing sector is relatively low. However, the share of water 10
consumption in the Manufacturing sector is much lower than the economic value created by the sector. 11
Sichuan has the most significant water consumption in manufacturing (4.0 billion m³), followed by 12
Henan (3.5 billion m³), accounting for 17.2% and 19.5% of total water consumption, respectively. 13
As a solid energy base in China, the mining industry in the YRB consumes large amounts of water. 14
Sichuan has the highest water consumption (760 million m³) and the highest proportion in Shanxi (290 15
million m³), accounting for 4.8% of the province's total water consumption. In transportation, the highest 16
water consumption is in Sichuan (220 million m³), followed by Shandong (110 million m³), which is 17
significantly higher than other provinces. Waterway transportation has a large capacity and low cost 18
compared to land and air transportation, but water consumption is significantly higher than other modes. 19
The interior is inland except for Shandong, and the YR is poorly navigated, lacking large-scale shipping. 20
Only Sichuan can utilize water transportation through the Yangtze River channel. Only two provinces, 21
Sichuan and Shandong, have the conditions for water transportation. 22
The inside VWT of the YRB shows a west-to-east flow. As shown in Figure 3, Shandong and Henan 5
have the highest virtual water inflow. Inner Mongolia contributes 920 million m³, and Gansu contributes 6
1.16 billion m³, accounting for 53.5% and 68.2% of the total virtual water inflow from the two provinces, 7
respectively. As a consumer province, Shaanxi also contributed 69.6% of the virtual water flow to 8
Shandong and Henan. In the YRB, 49.7% of the virtual water flows into Shandong and Henan, but only 9
27.2% of the virtual water flows out of the two provinces. 10

From Fig. 4, we can see that Agriculture is the largest sector of virtual water outflow. Among them, 7 the virtual water outflow from agriculture in Gansu (1.5 billion m³) and Inner Mongolia (1.6 billion m³) 8 accounts for a higher proportion of the virtual water outflow in the province, 91.4% and 86.6%, 9 respectively. The main flows from Agriculture are in the direction of manufacturing and construction in 10 Shandong and Henan. Inner Mongolia and Gansu provinces have 28.8% and 32.2% of virtual water in 11 the Agriculture sector flowing into the Manufacturing sector in Henan and Shandong provinces, 12 respectively. Agriculture is increasingly being used in the Construction sector. China has taken strict 13 regulatory measures against burning straw or agricultural products. Large quantities of straw are made 14
into low-cost and highly fire-resistant construction formwork. Construction mixes made from straw are 1 widely used in the construction industry. 2 Manufacturing has the second-highest percentage of virtual water flow in each province. The Henan 3 Manufacturing industry has the highest virtual water flow at 280 million m³, representing 19.4%. The 4 main flows from Manufacturing are in the direction of each province's Manufacturing. For example, in 5 Henan and Sichuan, the two provinces plan to have equipment manufacturing as the pillar industry in the 6 province. Water resources are hidden in the appropriate equipment to transfer products to other provinces 7 to participate in Manufacturing. In real estate construction, water has also completed the transfer from 8 the production region to the consumption region. The homogeneity of the industrial structure makes the 9 VWT to the manufacturing sector within the YRB roughly the same. The heterogeneity between 10 industries makes the VWT to the provinces of manufacturing industries differ from province to province. 11 The heterogeneity of energy endowments has led to significant differences in the development of 12 the power sector across provinces. It makes the share of the virtual water flow of Mining and Public 13 services vary widely. The main flow of the Mining flows to the Manufacturing and Construction in the 14 provinces. However, virtual water flows to relatively rare regions but to economically developed regions. 15 The same applies to virtual water flow in Public services. 16 3.3. The Analysis of the outside Virtual Water Trade of the YRB 17 The YRB shows a virtual net water inflow (15.0 billion m³). However, YRB has a disproportionately 18 high WSI compared to other regions and still contributes a significant amount of virtual water to other 19 regions. Virtual water in the YRB flows mainly to China's economically developed and densely populated 20 regions. As shown in Fig. 7, the YRB outflow of the virtual water is 27.2 billion m³. However, the multi-21 year average natural annual runoff of the YR is only 58 billion m³, which means that the virtual water 22 outflow from the YRB is equivalent to the net flow of half of the YR each year. The total inflow is 42.2 23 billion m³, mainly from remote regions with few populations. 24

As shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, the main destinations of virtual water in the YRB are the Eastern 6 coast (4.8 billion m³), the Southern coast (4.7 billion m³), and Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (4.2 billion m³). 7 Virtual water flowing to the three regions accounts for 50.1% of the total virtual water flow out of the 8 YRB, and the GDP of the three regions accounts for 45.7% of China's GDP. However, not all three 9 regions are water-poor regions, especially the Southern coast, which is traditionally water-rich. Water-10 rich regions still need to transfer a large amount of virtual water from the water-poor YRB each year, 11 increasing the pressure on water resources in the YRB and limiting the development of the YRB. 12 The virtual water inflow to the YRB is 44.1 billion m³. The most significant contributor is the middle 13 reaches of the Yangtze River, which contributes 10.0 billion m³ and represents 22.7% of the total inflow. 14
It is followed by the Western region, where the provinces of Xinjiang and Tibet transferred 8.7 billion 1 m³ of virtual water to the YRB. As the least developed region in the country, the Western region supports 2 the economic development of YRB and other regions in the central and eastern cities by providing low-3 value-added products. Xinjiang, in particular, provides a large amount of water despite its high-water 4 stress index. In Xinjiang, more than 50% of agriculture production is exported to other provinces as 5 intermediate inputs or final products. 6

As shown in Fig. 7, agricultural VWT is mainly transferred from less developed regions to 13 developed regions. The western region accounts for 98% of the virtual agricultural water outflow (28.6 14 billion m³). It is followed by the northeast region (24.5 billion m³), which represents 88.1%. The main 15
outflows of virtual agricultural water in both regions were agriculture on the eastern and southern coasts 1 and manufacturing in the YRB. In contrast, the virtual agricultural water in the YRB went mainly to 2 construction in the provinces. The second largest virtual water outflow sector is manufacturing. The 3 highest virtual water outflow from manufacturing is in the middle reaches of the Yangtze River (8.9 4 billion m3), representing 26.5%, followed by the eastern coast (6.4 billion m³), accounting for 29.6%. 5 The central outflow of virtual water from manufacturing industries in each region is each province's 6 manufacturing and construction industries, especially in the YRB. Virtual water outflow from the service 7 industry in developed regions is higher than in less developed regions. Among virtual water flows from 8 the service sector, the southern coast (520 million m³) and Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (420 million m³) 9 account for the highest proportion of virtual water use in the region, at 5.5% and 5.1%, respectively. The 10 VWT in the service sector is a mutual transfer of services between multiple regions, with specific input 11 areas favoring densely populated regions. 12

sections.heading: 4. Discussion and policy implications 13
sections.text:
With economic development, the production factors gradually shift from primary to secondary and 14
tertiary industries. The YRB contributes 36.0% of the nation's food each year. Water scarcity in the YRB 15
will hurt China's food security. In addition, the YRB is rich in mineral resources and has significant 16
strategic resources, such as rare earth. However, the exploitation of resources needs a vast water demand. 17
Water scarcity will plague the exploitation of resources in the YRB and threaten China's energy security. 18
The less developed regions of the YRB, especially the water-scarce regions, deliver a large amount of 19
virtual water to the developed regions each year. Developed regions import high water-consuming 20
products from the YRB to meet demand at the expense of the ecological environment of the YRB. 21
Therefore, the VWT structure and scale of YRB need to be adjusted and improved. According to the 22
VWT situation of each province, construct the VWT compensation mechanism. 23
Along with improving water consumption efficiency in each province, the sectoral water quotas of 1
each province are dynamically adjusted. Through water compensation, virtual water outflow provinces 2
can carry out technological innovation and industrial upgrading. This would effectively improve the 3
efficiency of local water consumption. Virtual water inflow provinces exchange economic losses for 4
ecological values. This will help residents optimize their water consumption patterns and increase water 5
conservation awareness, improving water efficiency. 6
Contrary to the direction of VWT, resource-intensive and highly polluting industries are moving 7
from developed to less developed regions. In the YRB, the industrial shift is from the downstream to the 8
upstream regions. The YRB is ecologically fragile and has many high water-consuming industries. 9
China's resource-intensive and highly polluting industries are now moving from the east to the central 10
and western parts of the country. In the short term, these industries will increase local GDP. However, in 11
the long run, the development model based on the high water-consuming industries will create a vicious 12
circle of "population outflow and environmental degradation." People move from less developed to 13
developed regions in pursuit of a better living environment and educational resources for future 14
generations. The outflow of population, exceptionally high-quality talent, will lead to a talent gap in the 15
YRB. It prevents water-intensive industries from upgrading, Deteriorating the living environment, and 16
causing more population loss. The upstream governments in the YRB should actively cultivate successive 17
alternative industries and selectively accept industrial transfers from eastern regions. 18
Resource endowments, and political factors, drive the distribution of high water-consuming 19
industries. The widening of water-consuming industries is unrealistic. The policymakers should shift 20
their primary objective to harmonizing water-consuming industries with the local water environment. It 21
is critical for water-scarce regions, especially production-oriented regions (e.g., Ningxia, Inner 22
Mongolia). In addition, water-scarce regions should adjust the structure of export products and reduce 1
the share of high water-consuming industries. (Feng et al., 2014; Zeitoun et al., 2010) . 2
5.Conclusions 3
The main objective of this study was to evaluate the VWT of the YRB to achieve sustainable water 4
management and the Ecological conservation and high-quality development of the Yellow River Basin. 5
Based on the environmentally extended input-output model, we mapped the inside and outside VWT in 6
the YRB. In this study, we estimated the multi-sectoral water at the provincial level based on the China 7
High-Resolution Emission Gridded Database and previous Water Resources Bulletins, which ensures 8
consistent sources of water withdrawal data. The following principal conclusions were drawn. 9
The water scarcity in the YRB is still severe. The YRB is a virtual water inflow region with a total 10
net inflow of 16.9 billion m³. This means that YRB still has water scarcity, although YR is the second 11
longest river in China. However, despite its high WSI, YRB has exported 27.2 billion m³ of virtual water 12
to other regions, equivalent to the annual runoff of half the YR. Agriculture makes the most significant 13
contribution, accounting for 75.1% of the total virtual water outflow. The following is Manufacturing, 14
accounting for 13.2%. The massive outflow of virtual water from both sectors exacerbates the water 15
scarcity in the YRB. 16
VWT exacerbates water inequity within the YRB. Virtual water shows a flow from poorer to more 17
prosperous regions. Virtual water outflows are generally higher than inflows in poor provinces. Henan 18
and Shandong consumed 49.7% of the total VWT in the YRB but only contributed 27.2%. The current 19
VWT model is conducive to alleviating the water scarcity in the rich regions of the YRB, but it further 20
aggravates the water scarcity in the poor regions. 21 22
